thread.title: ANZ and Contact weigh on NZ sharemarket
thread.title_full: ANZ and Contact weigh on NZ sharemarket

author: news.com.au
title: ANZ and Contact weigh on NZ sharemarket
text:
NEW Zealand shares have fallen, with ANZ Banking Group down on its $A3 billion equity raising while Contact Energy declined in another day of heavy trading following Origin Energy's exit.
THE S&P/NZX 50 Index dropped 60.03 points, or one per cent, to 5868.66 on Friday.
Within the index, 37 stocks fell, eight rose and five were unchanged. Turnover was $322 million, compared to a daily average in July of $142 million, and included $196 million of Contact. Fonterra Shareholders' Fund, whose units are entitled to the dividends from Fonterra's ordinary shares, rose 5.2 per cent to $4.90 after the dairy company cut its farmgate milk payout forecast as expected, while offering financial support to its farmers and flagging a higher dividend. "The earnings per share was upgraded to a range of between 40 cents and 50 cents per share from market expectations of 36 cents, implying a dividend of about 31.5 cents," said Rickey Ward, JBWere's NZ equity manager. "On the current price at the time it gives you a dividend yield of above six per cent, so it starts to look like a really high dividend stock with the upgrade." Contact fell 1.3 per cent to $5.15, the first decline since Origin sold its controlling stake for $4.65 a share earlier this week, vastly boosting the liquidity and market weighting of the stock. Some 32 million shares changed hands on Friday. ANZ fell 6.8 per cent to $34.13 after the bank followed National Australia Bank in raising equity capital requirements to satisfy regulatory requirements in Australia. Kathmandu Holdings fell 0.6 per cent to $1.74 after Briscoe Group controlling shareholder Rod Duke said his takeover offer, at an implied price of $1.80, "fully reflects the value of Kathmandu shares".
